results.title: South west symphony
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow and Cinesound for the Tourist Development Authority of Victoria
results.brief_description: A lyrical account of the scenic beauties of Victoria’s south west coastal region. Beginning with aerial shots and street scenes of the city of Melbourne and ending at historical Portland. Also visits many of the higlights along the Great Ocean Road, including Geelong, Lorne, Warrnambool and the 12 apostles. Cinematography by Ross King. Narrated by Len London. (Awards: AFI Silver award 1965 Travel Category)

results.title: The Magnetic north
results.creator_credit: Lee Robinson, Dennis Hill Productions, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Waratah Film Productions
results.brief_description: The attractions of the Northern Territory and the development of Darwin as a tourist centre. The tropical winter brings numerous visitors from the south. Anthropologists come to study Aboriginal rock paintings, crocodile hunters come in search of adventure, business men and tourists come eager to explore the by-ways of this part of Australia and to join the locals in their annual July Festival.

results.title: Lucky break at Wrest Point Casino
results.creator_credit: Roger Clarke, Peter Kay and Tasmanian State Film Unit
results.brief_description: A promotional film featuring Wrest Point Casino in Hobart. An American personality briefly gives his impressions of the city of Hobart, including the harbour, restaurants, the casino and the history of the city.

results.title: Encounter Bay
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Shepherd and S A Government Tourist Bureau
results.brief_description: Encounter Bay, where the Murray River enters the sea, has a colorful history of whaling stations and ship wrecks. Bleached bones, rusty anchors, and museums remain to testify. Now Victor Harbour, Port Elliot, and Goolwa are popular holiday resorts. Luxurious accomodation, miles of surf beaches, golf courses, and natural beauty have made it a playground for people of all ages.

results.title: Australia's greatest river
results.brief_description: A study of the Murray River and the countryside and towns along its banks. Emphasizes the danger of over stocking, over cropping, and forest fires, and shows how steps are being taken to overcome these.
results.description: A study of the Murray River and the countryside and towns along its banks. Emphasizes the danger of over stocking, over cropping, and forest fires, and shows how steps are being taken to overcome these.

results.title: Polka-dotting Royal Exhibition Building
results.brief_description: Hugh McSpeeden is a Melbourne-based lighting and projection artist who has been involved with lighting for new music, dance, artists and festivals since 1968. His early 1980s projection of the Royal Exhibition Building in Melbourne were revolutionary and a precursor to outdoor festival projections.

constellations_other.name: Circling expanded cinema
constellations_other.description: Explore how expanded cinema like Lis Rhodes' Light Music connects to film composers, experimental materials and virtual reality.

results.description:
Hugh (aka Humania) is a Melbourne-based lighting and projection artist who has been involved with lighting for new music, dance, artists and festivals since 1968. A pioneer of outdoor projection in Australia, Hugh uses projectors as a musician would an instrument or a painter a palette, utilising lasers, slides, dyes, fluids and special effects to create unique images. He uses as his canvas surfaces as diverse as buildings, landscapes and beaches.

  • The Light Show

His early 1980s projection of the Royal Exhibition Building in Melbourne were revolutionary and a precursor to outdoor projections, such as those featured in White Night and Vivid.
description_for_label:

He uses as his canvas surfaces as diverse as buildings, landscapes and beaches.

  • The Light Show

His early 1980s projection of the Royal Exhibition Building in Melbourne were revolutionary and a precursor to outdoor projections, such as those featured in White Night and Vivid.

results.title: Daybill for the American release of Jedda
results.credit_line: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.
results.brief_description: Jedda represented a lot of historic firsts for the Australian moving image, not just in the story it was telling but how that story was told. The first fully funded Australian narrative feature to be shot in colour in the country, it used a colour process known as the Belgian Gevacolor so it was possible to shoot on location among the Australian landscape.

results.title: Love serenade
results.creator_credit: Jan Chapman, Mandy Walker, Shirley Barrett, AFFC and Saddleback Productions
results.brief_description:
Two bored sisters, Dimity and Vicki-Ann, live in the small country town of Sunray. Their new neighbour, a brooding self-centered type, formerly star D.J. of a drive-time programme on Brisbane radio, threatens to turn the sisters’ world upside down. Dimity and Vicki-Ann find themselves in competition for his affections as each develops a severe crush on the aging Lothario with a predilection for 70’s music and young women. Awards: Cannes International Film Festival 1996: Camera d’Or for Shirley Barrett. Also available on VHS.

Credits: Producer, Jan Chapman ; director, writer, Shirley Barrett ; photography, Mandy Walker.
Cast: Miranda Otto, Rebecca Frith, George Shevtsov, John Alansu.

results.title: Travelling light. Parklands [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Helen Bowden, Mandy Walker, Kathryn Millard, Soft Fruit, Showtime Australia, South Australian Film Corporation, New South Wales Film and Television Office and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: Travelling Light: Set in Adelaide in the 1970s comes writer/director Kathryn Millard’s debut feature film. Leanne Ferris (Pia Miranda) is supposed to be embracing her studies to become a teacher but is caught up in the social change and dynamism of the era when women and youth, in particular, were finding a new generation’s independence. The restrictive nature 1970s Australian society places on the married women in her life (Mum and elder sister Bronwyn) infuse Leanne with a drive to find her own path by becoming a photographer. Sexual forays, drug taking and poetry help shape Leanne’s young adulthood. Cast includes: Sacha Horler, Tim Draxl, Marshall Napier, Heather Mitchell, Simon Burke, Kestie Morassi, Tamblyn Lord. “Parklands” [307794]: Rosie (Cate Blanchett) is a young woman who returns to her home in Adelaide for her father’s (Tony Martin) funeral. This intriguing short film follows the path Rosie takes to solve the mystery of her father’s death. Talking with old friends, looking through diaries and photographs - reliving her childhood, she comes to understand the life of the man she called her father.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Helen Bowden, Mandy Walker, Kathryn Millard, Soft Fruit, Showtime Australia, South Australian Film Corporation, New South Wales Film and Television Office and Film Finance Corporation Australia

results.title: Life
results.creator_credit: Elisa Argenzio, Mandy Walker, Lawrence Johnston, Rough Trade Pictures and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Johnston’s debut feature following on from his award winning shorts ‘Night Out’ and ‘Eternity’, is a dynamic re-visioning of actor/playwright John Brumpton’s theatre piece “Containment” that focused on the situation of inmates in the segregated HIV positive section of an Australian prison. To describe Johnston’s beautifully composed, movingly rendered, emotionally shattering film as ‘an AIDS prison drama’ denies it the full range and reach of its compelling grip on any number of wider issues and universal concerns. Brumpton forcefully fleshes out the lead role of quick-tempered hardened Des, a crim who tests positive and is sent to T2 division. His relationship with his cell-mate Ralph is vividly evoked via subliminal flashbacks and interaction between themselves and amongst the other inmates of T2. Photography, Mandy Walker. Cast: John Brumpton, David Tredinnick, Robert Morgan, Belinda McClory, Noel Jordan.
